title: List of works by James Harrison
data: Whalley Range , Greater Manchester 53°27′19″N 2°15′37″W / 53.4554°N 2.2603°W / 53.4554 ; -2.2603 ( St Margaret 's Church , Whalley Range )
A new church costing £6,000 ( equivalent to £630,000 in 2019 ) , paid for by Samuel Brooks , a banker who was developing the area
Chester , Cheshire 53°11′19″N 2°53′27″W / 53.1887°N 2.8907°W / 53.1887 ; -2.8907 ( St Michael 's Church , Chester )
Largely rebuilt , but retaining interior fabric from the older church . It closed as a church in 1972-73 , and was converted into a heritage centre
Chester , Cheshire 53°11′14″N 2°53′33″W / 53.1871°N 2.8926°W / 53.1871 ; -2.8926 ( Trustee Savings Bank , Chester )
Designed in Tudor Gothic style . An extension was added in the 1970s and the building was converted into a restaurant
Upton , Chester , Cheshire 53°12′57″N 2°53′16″W / 53.2157°N 2.8879°W / 53.2157 ; -2.8879 ( Holy Ascension Church , Upton , Chester )
Built in 14th-century style . Transepts were added in 1958 and 1967
Handley , Cheshire 53°06′55″N 2°47′56″W / 53.1154°N 2.7989°W / 53.1154 ; -2.7989 ( All Saints Church , Handley )
The nave was rebuilt in Decorated style , re-using the roof of 1661 . The chancel and vestry were added in 1891
Chester , Cheshire 53°11′29″N 2°53′27″W / 53.1913°N 2.8909°W / 53.1913 ; -2.8909 ( St Nicholas ' Chapel , Chester )
Harrison converted the former medieval chapel into concert hall . It was later changed to be used as a shop . The site is a Scheduled monument
Hough Green , Chester , Cheshire 53°10′47″N 2°54′53″W / 53.1796°N 2.9147°W / 53.1796 ; -2.9147 ( Christ Church , Chester )
Hawarden , Flintshire , Wales 53°11′09″N 3°01′33″W / 53.1859°N 3.0258°W / 53.1859 ; -3.0258 ( St Deiniol 's Church , Hawarden )
Restored by Harrison , but badly damaged by fire in 1857
Capenhurst , Cheshire 53°15′26″N 2°56′56″W / 53.2573°N 2.9489°W / 53.2573 ; -2.9489 ( Holy Trinity Church , Capenhurst )
New church . The tower was added in 1889-90 by John Douglas
Since converted into a private house
( With J. and J. M. Hay ) A Presbyterian church , since closed
Substantially rebuilt in Gothic Revival style
An early example of Black-and-white Revival ( vernacular ) architecture in Chester
Tattenhall Hall , Tattenhall , Cheshire 53°07′04″N 2°46′07″W / 53.1179°N 2.7685°W / 53.1179 ; -2.7685 ( Haybarn , Tattenhall Hall )
It is the best and the least-altered building on the model farm belonging to the hall . Built for Robert Barbour
Tattenhall Hall , Tattenhall , Cheshire 53°07′07″N 2°46′19″W / 53.1186°N 2.7719°W / 53.1186 ; -2.7719 ( Gate piers and wing walls , Tattenhall Hall )
Chester , Cheshire 53°11′14″N 2°53′24″W / 53.1873°N 2.8899°W / 53.1873 ; -2.8899 ( St Olave 's Church , Chester )
A simple church dating from the 11th century , restored by Harrison
Dunham on the Hill , Cheshire 53°15′07″N 2°47′33″W / 53.2520°N 2.7924°W / 53.2520 ; -2.7924 ( St Luke 's Church , Dunham on the Hill )
A new church in early 14th-century style
Chester , Cheshire 53°11′11″N 2°53′28″W / 53.1863°N 2.8911°W / 53.1863 ; -2.8911 ( Church of St Mary-on-the Hill , Chester )
Renewal of the exterior stonework and rebuilding of the top of the tower . Harrison also designed a memorial in the church to William Currie , who died in 1834
Chester , Cheshire 53°11′24″N 2°53′33″W / 53.1901°N 2.8926°W / 53.1901 ; -2.8926 ( God 's Providence House , Chester )
Virtual replacement of a house dating from 1652 , using some of the original carved timber
A new church replacing an older church on the site . Harrison died before it was completed . It is now the Guildhall
intro: James Harrison (1814-66) was an English architect who worked mainly in Chester, Cheshire. He worked mainly on churches - building new churches, rebuilding old churches, and making amendments and alterations to existing churches. Harrison also designed a number of houses in the Queen's Park area of Chester, and farm buildings on the Bolesworth estate. Harrison and Thomas Mainwaring Penson were the first architects to introduce buildings of the Black-and-white Revival to Chester in the 1850s. His rebuilding of God's Providence House in Watergate Street is described as the first conservation case in the modern sense.
